channel.title: Screen Resolution not supported
channel.description:
So I bought a new video card for my desktop and it took me like 2 hours to setup the drivers on xp. Eventually I got it, I then start up ubuntu and install the driver which took ~ 1 minute. I had to restart for the changes to take effect, but when I restarted (I'm guessing that installing the driver changed the resolution for me) the resolution/refresh rate was not supported by my monitor.
tltr: How can I change my resolution/refresh rate without actually being able to see anything on my monitor as the current resolution isn't supported by my monitor?
Edit: I just found out that it isn't a resolution/refresh rate problem. After installing the ati driver and restarting, the screen goes blank. It's not the resolution because I also tried a more capable monitor. I also searched around and found out that other people were having the same issue. There was some stuff about repairing xorg.config but it didn't work for me.

item.title: Screen Resolution not supported
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

I downloaded the catalyst driver but upon restarting the whole screen went purple. I think if I were to play with the driver in graphics failsafe mode I could have fixed it. But as for now I’m abandoning linux until after I finish my exams, it’s taking too much of my time.

Thanks for the help admins & weible.

And btw, I did find a way to stretch my monitor using the monitor. I also found out that screen is also over-sized in windows when I play a certain game at 1280*1024, so I’m guessing the problem was indeed the graphics card rather than the Linux driver.

Read full topic

item.title: Screen Resolution not supported
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

Its your monitor probably but I have had problems with ATI onboard on 7 where it was too small and I fixed that inside ATI catalyst control center using scaling option.

Read full topic

item.title: Screen Resolution not supported
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I think if you are using the closed-source ATI driver that program is already included. Do you know which driver you are using?

The setting to shrink or grow the displayed screen usually looks like this:

 ____________
|     ^      |
|     |      |
|     |      |
|     |      |
|     ↓      |

Read full topic

item.title: Screen Resolution not supported
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:10, topic:342367”][quote author=Radeon link=topic=438775.msg3226632#msg3226632 date=1275634740]
It doesn’t entirely fit on the screen. For example the date on the top right corner isn’t entirely on the screen, some of it is to the left of what my monitor is capable of displaying.
[/quote]

There’s a button on the monitor to fix that, I have to hold down “2” for a few seconds. It’s not an Ubuntu issue.[/quote]
I can adjust the position of the display using the monitor, but I can’t find anything to reduce it’s size. Even after adjusting the position, some of the desktop is still beyond what my monitor can display.

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:9, topic:342367”][quote author=Radeon link=topic=438775.msg3226666#msg3226666 date=1275642189]

No, don’t change distributions. Just run the ‘nvidia-settings’ command, you can install it with your package manager if you don’t have it already.

I actually have an ATi card and unfortunately I couldn’t find an equivalent of the nvidia-settings package
[/quote]

The AMD Catylyst control center?
http://www.phoronix.com/scan.php?page=article&item=amd_nvidia_panels&num=1

If I had an ATI card I could find out for sure.[/quote]

I couldn’t find it in the package manager. I’m gonna try and download it somewhere else this time and i’ll post back here after that.

Read full topic

item.title: Screen Resolution not supported
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:4, topic:342367”]What do you mean too big for your screen? 1360 is 1360

Sorta Offtopic: Why isn’t Ubuntu using conf-less xorg yet :/[/quote]
It doesn’t entirely fit on the screen. For example the date on the top right corner isn’t entirely on the screen, some of it is to the left of what my monitor is capable of displaying.

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:5, topic:342367”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=438775.msg3225791#msg3225791 date=1275560474]
Sorta Offtopic: Why isn’t Ubuntu using conf-less xorg yet
[/quote]

There is no xorg.conf with stock ubuntu, but so far with the nvidia driver I’ve had to make one so it loads that instead of the ‘nouveau’ driver.

@Radeon, how are you changing your resolution? Are you doing it with the ‘nvidia-settings’ command? You should be.[/quote]

I was doing it graphically, system>preferences>monitor. Would it be a good idea if I change to kubuntu or some other distribution in the hope that it would deal better with my graphics card?

Read full topic

item.title: Screen Resolution not supported
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Mopman:

Sorta Offtopic: Why isn’t Ubuntu using conf-less xorg yet

There is no xorg.conf with stock ubuntu, but so far with the nvidia driver I’ve had to make one so it loads that instead of the ‘nouveau’ driver.

@Radeon, how are you changing your resolution? Are you doing it with the ‘nvidia-settings’ command? You should be.

Read full topic

item.title: Screen Resolution not supported
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

Moparisthebest:

The file you need to change is /etc/X11/xorg.conf, not xorg.config so that might be the problem right there?

My attempt at repairing it was using a command (I can’t remember what it was exactly) I found on the ubuntu forums which I pasted into the terminal. Is there any other way I can go about ‘repairing’ xorg.conf?

A lot of people are having a similar problem. http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1307653

That particular one is for people with nVidia cards but I have come across many instances with the same problem on an ATi card.

EDIT:
I rebooted, selected recovery option in the boot menu. I then when into low graphic mode failsafe. I got it to restore original generic settings and rebooted again. For some reason it worked and the proprietary driver is enabled. Don’t ask me why :S

New problem: the current resolution 1360*768 is too big for my screen which is funny because this resolution was fine on windows.

Read full topic
